title: Panel

  title_text: Panel

  preference: main

  creation_date: Early 20th century

  creation_place_original_location: Straits Settlements

  styles_periods_indexing_terms: Chinese (culture or style)

  shape: rectangular

  materials_name: glass (material) metal thread cotton (textile)

  techniques_name: sewing (needleworking technique)

  object_colour: multicolored

  physical_appearance: This is a costume panel. It is long and bronze in colour
 featuring nine medallions in the center. The center medallion features a dragon motif
 while the other medallions feature other symbols such as a whisk
 a fan and a drum.

  subject_terms_1: Taoism symbolism (artistic concept) dragons folk costume

  subject_terms_2: Motifs Taoism Ethnic costume Symbolism Dragons Clothing and dress

  subject_terms_3: Chinese costumes Taoism

  sgcool_label_text: A dragon motif occupies the central lobed medallion
 and is flanked by auspicious Daoist symbols--the fly whisk
 fan
 pair of castanets
 and bamboo drum—similarly enclosed in lobed medallions.  The front- facing dragon was possibly inspired by Ming dynasty imperial court robes
 with the dragon symbolising the emperor’s centrality in the universe.  Pencil outlines of the designs in the cartouches are evident where some beads have fallen off.

metadata.physical_appearance: This is a costume panel. It is long and bronze in colour, featuring nine medallions in the center. The center medallion features a dragon motif, while the other medallions feature other symbols such as a whisk, a fan and a drum.
metadata.subject_terms_1: Taoism symbolism (artistic concept) dragons folk costume
metadata.subject_terms_2: Motifs Taoism Ethnic costume Symbolism Dragons Clothing and dress
metadata.sgcool_label_text: A dragon motif occupies the central lobed medallion, and is flanked by auspicious Daoist symbols--the fly whisk, fan, pair of castanets, and bamboo drum—similarly enclosed in lobed medallions.  The front- facing dragon was possibly inspired by Ming dynasty imperial court robes, with the dragon symbolising the emperor’s centrality in the universe.  Pencil outlines of the designs in the cartouches are evident where some beads have fallen off.
